Description: Fragment from shoulder of large closed pottery vessel (amphora?); white slip; glaze patchily fired; from the top: two bands at base of neck; band of tongues; friezes separated by bands with added red band lined in white: above, pendant lotus and bud frieze; below, animal frieze with part of goat, head reverted, rosettes in field. Interior reserved.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Incised mark "AP" on fragment. Published in Fairbanks 1928, p. 113, pl. XXXV, no. 324.2. Fairbanks, A.1928, Catalogue of Greek and Etruscan Vases, Boston.
Bibliographic references: Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 225, no. 122)
Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 113, pl. XXXV, no. 324.2)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.003)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4655 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
